pros: Brand name does not matter. Bad reputation, 737-Max  shame are few of them
cons:
I joined Boeing BT&E (simulation) with the hope of better prospect in term of technology and growth but it has been as huge mistake. After coming out of premium  institutes and working in top fortune 500 companies , it was a horrible experience. There is no definite work package, all they come in bit and pieces, no long term vision. Lack of expertise (both technical and managerial) from manager made it difficult to assess actual work effort  and required deliverable.s Often, interaction became a matter of interruption of work. More than half of team mates moved out the team/organisation  in last six months. 
Aggressive recruitment was done to fill the headcounts and most middle level managers were probably low performing individuals from similar domain. These  are good enough to ruin anybody's career. Even higher managements have no business to make it better. HR department exists for induction and exit process only. There is no work ethics, mostly when interacting  between cross functional teams and also in choosing favorite  employee (yes !! Yes Boss type)

review_title: AMT's point of view for Boeing.
job_title: Aircraft Test Technician A in Renton, WA
pros:
Overall it's a great company that has the given its employers the ability to expand beyond their parameters. They offer annual incentives and financially help anyone with the drive to further their education; furthering ones education is greatly appreciated and 'fiscally' rewarded within the company. 

They also provide adequate internal training for individuals who wish to change their working positions. In all if you have the incentive to better yourself, they will help you do it. It's impressive where an employee can start and how far they can reach within a few short years.
cons:
-Higher and more strenuous requirements for employees overall causes mistakes which will take more time to reprimand and in turn cost more money lastly further degrade our image and trust from our partners.

- A shrinking, less powerful union which its employees lose trust in as time passes by.

review_title: Huge management issues and huge lack of serious software/hardware/systems talent
pros:
union strong****
great 401k plan (no pension for employees after 2011 in washington state)
great healthcare 
great PTO (when i left for union members sick time off and paid time off were in seperate pools)
cons:
their salary is not competitive for tech roles in the seattle area
no stock bonuses when I was there
Management is the biggest issue by far, I have seen software engineering teams end up with managers with mechanical engineering backgrounds causing a clear difference in ideas between the engineers and leaders. Management cares only about metrics rather and personal contribution but ill add the union only makes this issue worse. Hiring talent is a joke, not only do they not offer competetive wages, there is a ton of red tape preventing getting good people, and finally the WORST issue by far for hiring is that the majority of interviews are incredibily easy and do not ask questions related to the job they are posted for. The interview process allows people who have no idea what they are doing join a team and become a drain on resources.

review_title: Worst decision to join Boeing India Engineering Center
pros: Brand name and major Aerospace

Pathetic senior management. Being an engineering manager it is a worst nightmare in Boeing India engineering team. Most of the senior management does not have any people management and technical background. Company like Boeing must see this else no doubt another 737 max like disaster would come soon. 
HR is only to say welcome to Boeing India and thanks for joining and leaving Boeing India. Pathetic work life balance for lower management and team members. Senior management must have a vision. Most of the time managers bagging for good work to come but it is worst than a service industry. They keep fooling around that we have One Boeing policy like a lie. Senior management brought people and managers whom they know already and also conducted their interviews and selected them. No ethics in most of the senior managers. Morning management preach you for Ethics, work life balance, inclusion, retaliation etc and evening they do the same. Every evening 2-4 hours extra meetings, any one challenge seniors are thrown out; specially in Boing India Engineering

job_title: DSP Algorithms Engineer in El Segundo, CA
pros:
- Good Benefits
- Excellent Retirement Benefits (6% company match + 3% for free)
- Overall pretty good work-life balance, flexible schedule
- Good coworkers, most are very smart and pleasant to work with
- Allowed to WFH full-time during Covid-19 (up until I left in mid-2020)
cons:
I worked in 2 different teams during my time at Boeing, the DSP Algorithms team and the Satellite Flight Software team. These were both under the Defense/Space side of Boeing, so I can only speak about my experience within that branch of the company.

BUREAUCRACY: 
Boeing is a huge company, so there’s a stifling amount of bureaucracy that you have to deal with here. Literally every step of your work has to be reviewed and approved by several people. Boeing loves to preach about innovation but the truth is that the bureaucracy stifles any breath of innovation, as there’s almost always a mentality of, “We’ve always done things this way! It works, so don’t change it!”

INCOMPETENT MANAGEMENT:
Almost all of the managers I worked with were frustrating to work with in some capacity, and many really didn't seem to care about their employees:

I was initially hired to work as a DSP Algorithms Engineer at Boeing. After a few months, I realized that the type of work that they do (Simulink & Matlab) was not what I wanted to spend 8-9 hours of my day on, so I asked management if I could switch to a team that works on software. They were initially understanding and supportive of my decision, but after only about 3 months being able to work on software, they pulled me back into doing systems engineering work for 6 months. The worst part was that they did not even give me this news through an in-person chat (this was pre-COVID); they simply notified me through an email... Because nothing screams "we care about our employees" like telling them they have to immediately switch back to doing the work they disliked for half a year through an email...

Another manager that I worked with for my first program basically micromanaged me and constantly asked me for my progress status almost every day at a certain point, because the program had slipped in schedule. I was a new-hire at the time, and was the only person actively working on verification, so I have no idea how they expected me to meet their schedule virtually alone.

The final task I had to complete for the systems engineering team before switching to the software team for the first time was a software tool to allow the hardware team to do some of their verification testing. This same manager slept on the code that I gave their team for 9 MONTHS before properly testing it, and then expected me to prioritize working on his program to debug that software tool while also working full-time on the software team. They had the audacity to claim that their program had “a much more pressing schedule” than the software team's, yet somehow didn't bother to test my software tool with their hardware for 9 months.

Another manager that I worked under did not seem to understand that I was frequently being pulled into doing work for both the systems and the software teams at the same time due to program schedules. They kept insisting that I put in a full 40 hours a week to keep up with my software tasks, and to only work on the “urgent” systems engineering task as overtime. This was right when COVID-19 and lockdowns were starting, and everyone was already anxious about the situation. Because I was frequently being bothered by my former team and the hardware team to help debug work that I hadn't touched for nearly a year, I was unable to complete all of the tasks I was given on the software team in time. This was held against me by this manager, who didn't allow me to officially switch into the software team due to many of my software tasks slipping schedule. Frustratingly, this same manager was the one that told my primary manager to reassign me back into doing systems work in the first place. They had me reassigned to a team outside of software, yet when I was back on software, complained that I wasn't getting the work done in time, which was also partly due to my lack of experience with the processes that the software team followed, which I could've avoided if I was never reassigned outside of the software team in the first place. This pathetic excuse of a manager was the biggest reason why I eventually left, as they obviously did not care about their employees.

LACK OF HANDS-ON WORK:
Both teams that I worked on while at Boeing involved working with the hardware. However, we engineers on these teams did not get the opportunity to WORK on or test our designs/code on actual hardware. Instead, ALL of the work that we did was tested in simulations. Yes, Boeing is so compartmentalized that the people who do hands-on testing with the hardware are completely separate teams, and in my experience, I never even worked with them. If you're like me and enjoy working with/seeing the physical side of your engineering efforts, Boeing is probably not the company you want to work for...

DEPRESSING WORK ENVIRONMENT: 
Across the 2 teams that I worked with while at Boeing, I worked in 3 different locations. All 3 were cube farms, with the last one before I left being the most depressing of all; it was basically a giant warehouse with about 100 cubes crammed into it. It was stuffy, contained no windows, and suffered from bad lighting. Forcing everyone to work from home because of the COVID situation was actually a bit of a blessing in this sense, as I no longer had to come into a stuffy, depressing cube farm everyday.

LACK OF AMBITION:
Like I said in the Pros section, many of the people (non-managers) I worked with were good and smart people, but you’d be hard-pressed to find any employees who truly enjoy their job and look forward to coming in to work everyday. A large amount of the people I worked with were either complacent in their current role or were applying to leave the company as soon as they could. This is a company where your ambition dies the longer you stay here.

review_title: I was warned...wish I had listened
pros: Good benefits. Great 401K. If you are okay with stupidity, it's not that difficult of a place to work. In other words, if you are a mediocre blustering blow hard, you will have found your people!
cons: I was told people referred to Boeing as "The Lazy B" because no one cared what they were doing. I assumed that this was just an exaggeration. Like many large, older organizations, people make such jokes. But they are not THAT bad. Well, this one IS that bad. It was no joke; lame, toxic culture, riddled with pompous, self-important jerks, ridiculous red tape, and stupid processes. The core culture has become so institutionalized they don't realize that they are mediocre at best. They have NO idea how to build software. They are so arrogant they don't listen to those who do. They favor surface over substance. Apparently, most of the employees had all pretty much given up; they resigned themselves to just wandering the halls sipping coffee blathering on about pointless things. The leadership is ineffectual and spineless. I was heavily recruited and had high hopes. It sounded like it was going to be exciting work and friendly people. It was not. I spoke to the manager who hired me maybe four times in three years. I was not alone. Our whole group recognized his lack of presence and absence of accountability> He was absent. I guess playing golf or hiding under his desk? We all joked about it. When he talked to us as a group, it was pathetic. Aspirational platitudes, dumb metaphors, silly business jargon.; no strategy. No idea about technology, training, or business, for that matter. Anyone with a brain entertained themselves during these nonsensical diatribes by playing buzzword bingo to try to stay awake. So, of course, he gets promoted. A shocking lack of critical thinking skills and lack of ethics. Innovation, diversity, integrity, just lip service. Pathetic. I regret taking the job.

review_title: Low Pay for Hours Worked, Cost of Living
pros:
Amazing company and co-workers, fantastic benefits and 401k match.

Tons of opportunity to further your education, bounce around different roles, and get to work on genuinely cool programs like Air Force One or the International Space Station.
cons:
Can't speak to other roles such as engineering or software development, but procurement roles are grossly underpaid for the cost of living in Seattle. Be prepared to live paycheck to paycheck if you don't have roommates to split rent with in the city, or be forced to live outside the city and commute an hour each way to work. 

Very steep learning curve as a new buyer, tough (outdated) systems to use, grueling government documentation / regulations, long hours, and the positions are known for their high turnover rate within the company.

Overall I'd say work at Boeing - just skip being a Buyer. You can find a similar role in the Seattle area for half the complexity and a much more livable salary.

review_title: Don’t work here if you’re young and technical
pros: If you can land a management or PM job, life can be cushy and you’ll be overpaid. Assuming they survive the regular layoffs, they can retire in place - hide in meetings all day, get paid big bucks to boss all the little technical people and snatch up the limited promotions since they get all the upper exposure. The lack of analysis or critical thinking required of a Boeing manager is incredible and comparable to working in government, if you’re in to that. So basically if you choose to work here, make absolute sure you’re headed in managerial path.
cons: If you are technical( engineer, programmer, technician) this is the worst place to be in the Puget Sound area. Technical roles are egregiously underpaid here so anyone even half decent evaporates leaving the complacent, lazy or unskilled ones behind. You’ll have mountains of work pulling the weight of all these retired in place people plus having extra work and status updates piled on top by multiple layers of managers and project managers. Don’t be fooled by reviews about work life balance at this company - it doesn’t apply to you if you’re technical and know your stuff. The most offensive part is after all these long hours and sometimes straight up verbal abuse by management, you’ll be rewarded with raise that can’t keep up with inflation and ZERO promotion potential. It’s well known with all the aged folks sticking around at Boeing it simply can’t afford to promote you or give you a meaningful raise. Meaning, your performance review will never match the outsized efforts you put out for the team or your disproportionate impact -it will be glossed over because they can only AFFORD minimal promotions and those will inevitably go to the nontechnical types who actually have the time to schmooze with upper management.

review_title: Company lacking technical depth and culture
pros: Some of the best benefits across the board in any industry, from 401k to tuition reimbursement. and steady employment for the most part as long as you perform basic expectations tied to your role. Gives flexibility to grow personally but only certain groups will actually allow you to grow professionally, either from a technical or non-technical standpoint. Flexible work schedule for most sites.
cons:
Both engineering and program senior leadership lack technical depth. The company is set up cross-functionally on paper, with program and engineering leaders reporting to different executives but both sides of the house still push for cost and schedule over all else (except for safety when it's immediately apparent). There isn't true back up on the engineering and technical front. The leaders lack technical depth to ask the right questions and guide hardware development vision. Leaders just want short term results and lack true long term vision. This leads to half-baked, lackluster engineering solutions that require significant updates because project leads don't listen to the technical input. This is exemplified by the major projects seen in the news but it permeates throughout smaller projects as well. These issues then cause more schedule delays which the PMO and executives blame engineers for being slow and inept when in fact they didn't want to hear it in the first place, leading to a toxic work cycle for those looking for a technical place to grow and succeed. Trying to come up with the best technical solution and technical due diligence is seen as "wasting time and money."

When leaders say they're there to help provided resources, they just call daily or weekly meetings for updates and to ask when it's going to be done and what's taking so long. They don't give REAL resources to drive closure to the problem at hand nor the freedom for engineers to develop the best solutions, only enough time, money, and pressure for band-aid solutions. Given so many leaders pride themselves on being both business and tech savvy, it's a surprise they fall for the sunken cost fallacy so easily.

Most technically capable employees see this culture and are leaving in droves.to competitors. Those who are left behind are those who can tell a good story but can't build or design the hardware Boeing was previously known for, resulting in a bloated, slow moving company with mediocre products.

pros: Benefits are good, 75% matching savings plan, good vacation levels if you stay a while. If you like being given a diverse set of assignments, then that is a positive for Boeing. Each assignment I get seems like it couldn't be more different than everything I've ever done before. Working on spacecraft thermal analysis one month, then requirement verification tracking the next, then designing and building plumbing for a laboratory cooling system six months after that. Boeing does not like to lay off people anymore, (they have a very good severance package), they have had some recently, but they will find you a new task somewhere rather than lay you off if at all possible. Many jobs can be done remotely, so supporting programs in other states without relocating is common now. Travel is usually involved though to some extent when supporting out of state programs.
cons: You are probably not going to have a stable work location. Any job from anyplace is Boeing's modo these days, which means they will assign people from all over the country to support programs as needed. Could mean you get to work remotely, but with that will likely come travel to some extent. In the aerospace market, Boeing is now trying to force lots of unpaid overtime on engineers to compete with the likes of SpaceX, and I have seen lots of bad decisions made trying to cut costs.

-Training is slow and boring and chances are your first 6 months to a year here will consist of sitting around and doing nothing .

review_title: Three G's - Get the money, Get the Experience, Get out
job_title: Manufacturing Manager K in Portland, OR
pros: Leads the industry in pay and benefits. You will get all the training that you could possibly hope for and be able to capitalize on unique benefits such as tuition re-imbursement to expand your college education and exposure to a diverse work force.
cons: Portland has created and perpetuates a culture of leadership that rewards "yes" people and rewards them accordingly. People that are skilled leaders at this factory do not fair near as well as those that are strictly managers who are able to follow checklists. Hypocrisy is an attribute you will need to be comfortable with to succeced at this factory. It is communicated that employee surveys are important as are yearly performance reviews however, high scoring individuals in these areas were people that were terminated during layoffs. Managers with outstanding Corrective Action Memos (CAM's) were given a free pass during last round of layoffs whereas those with excellent records were let go. Managers with outside experience including other Boeing locations are appalled at the Senior Leadership and Executive leadership culture that is in place currently. Several people have successfully transitioned to other Boeing locations and have done exceptionally well. Remember the three G's.

review_title: Great at First but Company Culture Failed Me
pros:
I love aviation so very much. Since when I was younger I knew I wanted to work in aviation. My last job was not a good fit for me and when I accepted this job I knew I would enjoy it. I was welcomed even with limited experience in the subject matter. I felt welcomed by every team member and I also saw the amazing benefits the company offered. I felt like I found my dream job to an extent. However, I had other experiences that others on my team did not have and I felt that was my advantage. I had support from others within the company to always do the best I can, even if I was not learning as fast as others wanted me to learn. COVID happened, and the challenge to work at home worked out for me, but only to an extent. The company has visions for inclusion and to end racism, but not for all groups. 

Overall:

- Have exciting products
- Have nice facilities
- Great benefits 
- Can work on really interesting stuff
cons:
Things have been turning for the worse for me where management has viewed me in a different light, compared to my more experienced colleagues. The interesting thing is many people tend to "fake it to you make it or lie on their resume." I did not and it seems management regrets hiring someone with limited experience. I have been told I have other issues I need to fix, but will not provide concrete written examples. Furthermore, due to COVID, the company did a major rehaul in business units and where they fall. Only time will tell if this will actually work. The company promotes inclusion and diversity, yet there are certain groups the company has failed to even put out a statement. The management team is failing me, not the company. However, the company does not provide many outlets for employees to voice their issues. In my last company, I had a clear understanding of where to go and the outcome benefited me and also benefited the manager in a way. 

There was a brief occurrence where I was judged on my uniform, but I clearly stated I was not staying in the office. If a company wants to promote inclusion and bring itself to work, management should not quickly judge someone's business professional attire. Why does someone have to wear a suit and tie to simply pick up something from their desk knowing they do not have meetings or will not interact with others. 

Also even if you work around the clock, it's not good enough for management. They do not say outright to work weekends and holidays but everyone does it. If you do not, then you're behind. I never was really able to disconnect during PTO, as work was always on my mind. Compared to my last company, the PTO at Boeing is better but depends on the team you work with. 

I do not feel welcomed and I am looking elsewhere for other opportunities to pursue my dreams to continue in the aviation industry. The office I work at unfortunately has limited opportunities and it is a challenge to do interesting things


- Management is not clear on expectations
- Management does not understand the picture

Technologically they are stuck in the 1990's. All work is done via excel spreadsheets. No linked systems, everything is done manually. SAP has been talked about for years and never implemented. 

Managers and directors do not care about the impact that their workers have on the rest of the company as long as their metrics look good. Purchasing can drag their heels on orders that impact production and it does not matter as long as their monthly metrics meet corporate standards.

review_title: The Right Manager Will Give You A Raise
job_title: Procurement Agent II in El Segundo, CA
pros:
9/80 Schedules Allow Flexibility
Good managers are out there, but you have to be lucky.
cons:
Other companies use updated software and pay better. Also, it's hard to get a raise (your manager has to like you). That explains the turnover.
Other engineers have expressed how behind the company is in terms of certain engineering functions. Part of the blame? The company refuses to put in competitive salaries to keep top employees.

Also, all the sexy engineering projects are left up to the top 5% of the company. So if you're not, then you might not find satisfaction. The company would rather not take the risk and acquire start-ups when they develop proven products with potential.

Fair wages and stable employment
75% matching up to 8% of your base wage in the 401K plan
Health plan selection is great and fair out of pocket
PTO is fair compared to other companies
cons: The company has moved away from it's roots as an engineering based firm that built airplanes and other technologies to a company that values shareholders and product sales over engineered in quality and customer satisfaction.

review_title: Great pay, toxic work environment. Hope they turn it around but the rot is DEEP.
job_title: Integral Fuel Cell Assembly B in Renton, WA
pros: Money, money, money. Some serious BS but the money is wonderful. Learned some great skills. Great pay, decent benefits, great retirement plan, fun building airplanes. There's some good managers but it completely depends on where you end up. One building may be great, another hell on earth.
cons: Upper management is paralyzed by the fear of losing their job nobody does anything to address the rampant problems facing the company. Morale is in the toilet, toxic work environment, lots of racism. I've met all kinds of people here, which can be cool. It can also be terrifying. Some serious troglodytes who don't get out much.

review_title: Your experience highly depends on the department you are in
pros: School tuition program paid fully for my bachelor's degree almost entirely and will pay for Master's programs (some strings attached). Exciting and dynamic work environment. massive growth potential if you drive your career like that. 90% of people are great, hard working individuals that genuinely want to do the right thing. incredibly cool opportunities.
cons: Transferring between business units can be very difficult, even if you previously worked in the role you are trying to take. Some managers can be awful and they seem to get rotated around and the problems they cause are not addressed. getting an out of sequence raise almost never happens, you just get one a year. typical big company problems exist that happen at all big companies.

pros: The have a some decent benefits like 6% matching 401K, a few different medical plans, good parental leave program for both parents, adoption assistance, and winter break.
cons: The people are not easy to work with and everyone has a blaming "not my job" mentality; I have never worked in a place where people are so unwilling to help. There are also so many hoops to jump through, it is nearly impossible to get anything done or make any meaningful changes. It isn't even fun going into the office because everyone wears headphones and pretends not to hear you just to avoid any type of conversation, whether work or personal. To say it is a negative environment is an understatement.

review_title: Not all it's made out to be.
pros: As an engineer very satisfying, you have the tools to do your job. Work on some of the latest technology.

Whilst this isn't the case across the whole of Boeing one bad apple can definitely have a big impact if they are your manager.

job_title: Procurement Agent II in Everett, WA
pros: Great work-life balance and they pay college tuition. Huge company so many opportunities to get exposed to different areas and learn many different things. In a supply chain role, you are given autonomy to learn whatever you want.
cons: The company is slow, bureaucratic and the pay isn't great for the supply chain. They are generally pretty terrible and onboarding people quickly. One problem is you end up on a team where things are really unbalanced, for example, 20% of the people are doing 80% of the work. It's happened to me on two separate teams. It's frustrating because you feel like you can't grow at the pace you want to. The annual performance evaluations are also confusing and vague so it's very easy to get screwed over, especially when you're new to the process.

Being thorough and doing the job right gets you a first class ticket to the unemployment line.

Lack of expertise (both technical and managerial) from manager made it difficult to assess actual work effort  and required deliverable.s Often, interaction became a matter of interruption of work. More than half of team mates moved out the team/organisation  in last six months. 
Aggressive recruitment was done to fill the headcounts and most middle level managers were probably low performing individuals from similar domain. These  are good enough to ruin anybody's career. Even higher managements have no business to make it better. HR department exists for induction and exit process only. There is no work ethics, mostly when interacting  between cross functional teams and also in choosing favorite  employee (yes !! Yes Boss type)

job_title: Aircraft Test Technician A in Renton, WA
pros:
Overall it's a great company that has the given its employers the ability to expand beyond their parameters. They offer annual incentives and financially help anyone with the drive to further their education; furthering ones education is greatly appreciated and 'fiscally' rewarded within the company.

union strong****

their salary is not competitive for tech roles in the seattle area
no stock bonuses when I was there
Management is the biggest issue by far, I have seen software engineering teams end up with managers with mechanical engineering backgrounds causing a clear difference in ideas between the engineers and leaders. Management cares only about metrics rather and personal contribution but ill add the union only makes this issue worse. Hiring talent is a joke, not only do they not offer competetive wages, there is a ton of red tape preventing getting good people, and finally the WORST issue by far for hiring is that the majority of interviews are incredibily easy and do not ask questions related to the job they are posted for. The interview process allows people who have no idea what they are doing join a team and become a drain on resources.

review_title: great benefits but lots of bureaucracy
pros: get to work on many cool projects and big airplanes with really nice individual people.
cons: more bureaucracy than you can imagine. every year there's a meeting about reducing costs, ideas get generated, the costs for completing some of the changes gets computed, then nothing changes. my theory is that so many people got their first job out of college at boeing that the whole management system is paralyzed. they can not imagine doing things any different because they've never experienced anything else, no other working experience to draw from. They've lost the ability to optimize their own system.

Every evening 2-4 hours extra meetings, any one challenge seniors are thrown out; specially in Boing India Engineering

job_title: DSP Algorithms Engineer in El Segundo, CA
pros:
- Good Benefits
- Excellent Retirement Benefits (6% company match + 3% for free)
- Overall pretty good work-life balance, flexible schedule
- Good coworkers, most are very smart and pleasant to work with
- Allowed to WFH full-time during Covid-19 (up until I left in mid-2020)
cons:
I worked in 2 different teams during my time at Boeing, the DSP Algorithms team and the Satellite Flight Software team. These were both under the Defense/Space side of Boeing, so I can only speak about my experience within that branch of the company.

BUREAUCRACY: 
Boeing is a huge company, so there’s a stifling amount of bureaucracy that you have to deal with here. Literally every step of your work has to be reviewed and approved by several people. Boeing loves to preach about innovation but the truth is that the bureaucracy stifles any breath of innovation, as there’s almost always a mentality of, “We’ve always done things this way! It works, so don’t change it!”

INCOMPETENT MANAGEMENT:
Almost all of the managers I worked with were frustrating to work with in some capacity, and many really didn't seem to care about their employees:

I was initially hired to work as a DSP Algorithms Engineer at Boeing. After a few months, I realized that the type of work that they do (Simulink & Matlab) was not what I wanted to spend 8-9 hours of my day on, so I asked management if I could switch to a team that works on software. They were initially understanding and supportive of my decision, but after only about 3 months being able to work on software, they pulled me back into doing systems engineering work for 6 months. The worst part was that they did not even give me this news through an in-person chat (this was pre-COVID); they simply notified me through an email... Because nothing screams "we care about our employees" like telling them they have to immediately switch back to doing the work they disliked for half a year through an email...

Another manager that I worked with for my first program basically micromanaged me and constantly asked me for my progress status almost every day at a certain point, because the program had slipped in schedule. I was a new-hire at the time, and was the only person actively working on verification, so I have no idea how they expected me to meet their schedule virtually alone.

The final task I had to complete for the systems engineering team before switching to the software team for the first time was a software tool to allow the hardware team to do some of their verification testing. This same manager slept on the code that I gave their team for 9 MONTHS before properly testing it, and then expected me to prioritize working on his program to debug that software tool while also working full-time on the software team. They had the audacity to claim that their program had “a much more pressing schedule” than the software team's, yet somehow didn't bother to test my software tool with their hardware for 9 months.

Another manager that I worked under did not seem to understand that I was frequently being pulled into doing work for both the systems and the software teams at the same time due to program schedules. They kept insisting that I put in a full 40 hours a week to keep up with my software tasks, and to only work on the “urgent” systems engineering task as overtime. This was right when COVID-19 and lockdowns were starting, and everyone was already anxious about the situation. Because I was frequently being bothered by my former team and the hardware team to help debug work that I hadn't touched for nearly a year, I was unable to complete all of the tasks I was given on the software team in time. This was held against me by this manager, who didn't allow me to officially switch into the software team due to many of my software tasks slipping schedule. Frustratingly, this same manager was the one that told my primary manager to reassign me back into doing systems work in the first place. They had me reassigned to a team outside of software, yet when I was back on software, complained that I wasn't getting the work done in time, which was also partly due to my lack of experience with the processes that the software team followed, which I could've avoided if I was never reassigned outside of the software team in the first place. This pathetic excuse of a manager was the biggest reason why I eventually left, as they obviously did not care about their employees.

LACK OF HANDS-ON WORK:
Both teams that I worked on while at Boeing involved working with the hardware. However, we engineers on these teams did not get the opportunity to WORK on or test our designs/code on actual hardware. Instead, ALL of the work that we did was tested in simulations. Yes, Boeing is so compartmentalized that the people who do hands-on testing with the hardware are completely separate teams, and in my experience, I never even worked with them. If you're like me and enjoy working with/seeing the physical side of your engineering efforts, Boeing is probably not the company you want to work for...

DEPRESSING WORK ENVIRONMENT: 
Across the 2 teams that I worked with while at Boeing, I worked in 3 different locations. All 3 were cube farms, with the last one before I left being the most depressing of all; it was basically a giant warehouse with about 100 cubes crammed into it. It was stuffy, contained no windows, and suffered from bad lighting. Forcing everyone to work from home because of the COVID situation was actually a bit of a blessing in this sense, as I no longer had to come into a stuffy, depressing cube farm everyday.

LACK OF AMBITION:
Like I said in the Pros section, many of the people (non-managers) I worked with were good and smart people, but you’d be hard-pressed to find any employees who truly enjoy their job and look forward to coming in to work everyday. A large amount of the people I worked with were either complacent in their current role or were applying to leave the company as soon as they could. This is a company where your ambition dies the longer you stay here.

review_title: I was warned...wish I had listened
pros: Good benefits. Great 401K. If you are okay with stupidity, it's not that difficult of a place to work. In other words, if you are a mediocre blustering blow hard, you will have found your people!
cons: I was told people referred to Boeing as "The Lazy B" because no one cared what they were doing. I assumed that this was just an exaggeration. Like many large, older organizations, people make such jokes. But they are not THAT bad. Well, this one IS that bad. It was no joke; lame, toxic culture, riddled with pompous, self-important jerks, ridiculous red tape, and stupid processes. The core culture has become so institutionalized they don't realize that they are mediocre at best. They have NO idea how to build software. They are so arrogant they don't listen to those who do. They favor surface over substance. Apparently, most of the employees had all pretty much given up; they resigned themselves to just wandering the halls sipping coffee blathering on about pointless things. The leadership is ineffectual and spineless. I was heavily recruited and had high hopes. It sounded like it was going to be exciting work and friendly people. It was not. I spoke to the manager who hired me maybe four times in three years. I was not alone. Our whole group recognized his lack of presence and absence of accountability> He was absent. I guess playing golf or hiding under his desk? We all joked about it. When he talked to us as a group, it was pathetic. Aspirational platitudes, dumb metaphors, silly business jargon.; no strategy. No idea about technology, training, or business, for that matter. Anyone with a brain entertained themselves during these nonsensical diatribes by playing buzzword bingo to try to stay awake. So, of course, he gets promoted. A shocking lack of critical thinking skills and lack of ethics. Innovation, diversity, integrity, just lip service. Pathetic. I regret taking the job.

review_title: Low Pay for Hours Worked, Cost of Living
pros:
Amazing company and co-workers, fantastic benefits and 401k match.

Tons of opportunity to further your education, bounce around different roles, and get to work on genuinely cool programs like Air Force One or the International Space Station.
cons:
Can't speak to other roles such as engineering or software development, but procurement roles are grossly underpaid for the cost of living in Seattle. Be prepared to live paycheck to paycheck if you don't have roommates to split rent with in the city, or be forced to live outside the city and commute an hour each way to work. 

Very steep learning curve as a new buyer, tough (outdated) systems to use, grueling government documentation / regulations, long hours, and the positions are known for their high turnover rate within the company.

Overall I'd say work at Boeing - just skip being a Buyer. You can find a similar role in the Seattle area for half the complexity and a much more livable salary.

review_title: Don’t work here if you’re young and technical
pros: If you can land a management or PM job, life can be cushy and you’ll be overpaid. Assuming they survive the regular layoffs, they can retire in place - hide in meetings all day, get paid big bucks to boss all the little technical people and snatch up the limited promotions since they get all the upper exposure. The lack of analysis or critical thinking required of a Boeing manager is incredible and comparable to working in government, if you’re in to that. So basically if you choose to work here, make absolute sure you’re headed in managerial path.
cons: If you are technical( engineer, programmer, technician) this is the worst place to be in the Puget Sound area. Technical roles are egregiously underpaid here so anyone even half decent evaporates leaving the complacent, lazy or unskilled ones behind. You’ll have mountains of work pulling the weight of all these retired in place people plus having extra work and status updates piled on top by multiple layers of managers and project managers. Don’t be fooled by reviews about work life balance at this company - it doesn’t apply to you if you’re technical and know your stuff. The most offensive part is after all these long hours and sometimes straight up verbal abuse by management, you’ll be rewarded with raise that can’t keep up with inflation and ZERO promotion potential. It’s well known with all the aged folks sticking around at Boeing it simply can’t afford to promote you or give you a meaningful raise. Meaning, your performance review will never match the outsized efforts you put out for the team or your disproportionate impact -it will be glossed over because they can only AFFORD minimal promotions and those will inevitably go to the nontechnical types who actually have the time to schmooze with upper management.

review_title: Company lacking technical depth and culture
pros: Some of the best benefits across the board in any industry, from 401k to tuition reimbursement. and steady employment for the most part as long as you perform basic expectations tied to your role. Gives flexibility to grow personally but only certain groups will actually allow you to grow professionally, either from a technical or non-technical standpoint. Flexible work schedule for most sites.
cons:
Both engineering and program senior leadership lack technical depth. The company is set up cross-functionally on paper, with program and engineering leaders reporting to different executives but both sides of the house still push for cost and schedule over all else (except for safety when it's immediately apparent). There isn't true back up on the engineering and technical front. The leaders lack technical depth to ask the right questions and guide hardware development vision. Leaders just want short term results and lack true long term vision. This leads to half-baked, lackluster engineering solutions that require significant updates because project leads don't listen to the technical input. This is exemplified by the major projects seen in the news but it permeates throughout smaller projects as well. These issues then cause more schedule delays which the PMO and executives blame engineers for being slow and inept when in fact they didn't want to hear it in the first place, leading to a toxic work cycle for those looking for a technical place to grow and succeed. Trying to come up with the best technical solution and technical due diligence is seen as "wasting time and money."

When leaders say they're there to help provided resources, they just call daily or weekly meetings for updates and to ask when it's going to be done and what's taking so long. They don't give REAL resources to drive closure to the problem at hand nor the freedom for engineers to develop the best solutions, only enough time, money, and pressure for band-aid solutions. Given so many leaders pride themselves on being both business and tech savvy, it's a surprise they fall for the sunken cost fallacy so easily.

Most technically capable employees see this culture and are leaving in droves.to competitors. Those who are left behind are those who can tell a good story but can't build or design the hardware Boeing was previously known for, resulting in a bloated, slow moving company with mediocre products.

pros: Benefits are good, 75% matching savings plan, good vacation levels if you stay a while. If you like being given a diverse set of assignments, then that is a positive for Boeing. Each assignment I get seems like it couldn't be more different than everything I've ever done before. Working on spacecraft thermal analysis one month, then requirement verification tracking the next, then designing and building plumbing for a laboratory cooling system six months after that. Boeing does not like to lay off people anymore, (they have a very good severance package), they have had some recently, but they will find you a new task somewhere rather than lay you off if at all possible. Many jobs can be done remotely, so supporting programs in other states without relocating is common now. Travel is usually involved though to some extent when supporting out of state programs.
cons: You are probably not going to have a stable work location. Any job from anyplace is Boeing's modo these days, which means they will assign people from all over the country to support programs as needed. Could mean you get to work remotely, but with that will likely come travel to some extent. In the aerospace market, Boeing is now trying to force lots of unpaid overtime on engineers to compete with the likes of SpaceX, and I have seen lots of bad decisions made trying to cut costs.

pros: Leads the industry in pay and benefits. You will get all the training that you could possibly hope for and be able to capitalize on unique benefits such as tuition re-imbursement to expand your college education and exposure to a diverse work force.
cons: Portland has created and perpetuates a culture of leadership that rewards "yes" people and rewards them accordingly. People that are skilled leaders at this factory do not fair near as well as those that are strictly managers who are able to follow checklists. Hypocrisy is an attribute you will need to be comfortable with to succeced at this factory. It is communicated that employee surveys are important as are yearly performance reviews however, high scoring individuals in these areas were people that were terminated during layoffs. Managers with outstanding Corrective Action Memos (CAM's) were given a free pass during last round of layoffs whereas those with excellent records were let go. Managers with outside experience including other Boeing locations are appalled at the Senior Leadership and Executive leadership culture that is in place currently. Several people have successfully transitioned to other Boeing locations and have done exceptionally well. Remember the three G's.

review_title: Great at First but Company Culture Failed Me
pros:
I love aviation so very much. Since when I was younger I knew I wanted to work in aviation. My last job was not a good fit for me and when I accepted this job I knew I would enjoy it. I was welcomed even with limited experience in the subject matter. I felt welcomed by every team member and I also saw the amazing benefits the company offered. I felt like I found my dream job to an extent. However, I had other experiences that others on my team did not have and I felt that was my advantage. I had support from others within the company to always do the best I can, even if I was not learning as fast as others wanted me to learn. COVID happened, and the challenge to work at home worked out for me, but only to an extent. The company has visions for inclusion and to end racism, but not for all groups. 

Overall:

- Have exciting products
- Have nice facilities
- Great benefits 
- Can work on really interesting stuff
cons:
Things have been turning for the worse for me where management has viewed me in a different light, compared to my more experienced colleagues. The interesting thing is many people tend to "fake it to you make it or lie on their resume." I did not and it seems management regrets hiring someone with limited experience. I have been told I have other issues I need to fix, but will not provide concrete written examples. Furthermore, due to COVID, the company did a major rehaul in business units and where they fall. Only time will tell if this will actually work. The company promotes inclusion and diversity, yet there are certain groups the company has failed to even put out a statement. The management team is failing me, not the company. However, the company does not provide many outlets for employees to voice their issues. In my last company, I had a clear understanding of where to go and the outcome benefited me and also benefited the manager in a way. 

There was a brief occurrence where I was judged on my uniform, but I clearly stated I was not staying in the office. If a company wants to promote inclusion and bring itself to work, management should not quickly judge someone's business professional attire. Why does someone have to wear a suit and tie to simply pick up something from their desk knowing they do not have meetings or will not interact with others. 

Also even if you work around the clock, it's not good enough for management. They do not say outright to work weekends and holidays but everyone does it. If you do not, then you're behind. I never was really able to disconnect during PTO, as work was always on my mind. Compared to my last company, the PTO at Boeing is better but depends on the team you work with. 

I do not feel welcomed and I am looking elsewhere for other opportunities to pursue my dreams to continue in the aviation industry. The office I work at unfortunately has limited opportunities and it is a challenge to do interesting things

cons: The company is slow, bureaucratic and the pay isn't great for the supply chain. They are generally pretty terrible and onboarding people quickly. One problem is you end up on a team where things are really unbalanced, for example, 20% of the people are doing 80% of the work. It's happened to me on two separate teams. The annual performance evaluations are also confusing and vague so it's very easy to get screwed over, especially when you're new to the process.

pros:
Once you're in, you're in. Easy to make connections, switch jobs, and do informational interviews. "Boeing is a career, not a job."

Lots of reshuffling and constant state of "ahhh!" due to the pandemic & 777 crash. This all leads to a toxic-ish work culture featuring poor communication, bad work-life balance, cliques + gossipy behavior. They have not handled virtual work & engagement well which results in feeling isolated.

Management mostly comprised of people who have been given the authority to make decisions they are not qualified to make, In other words, making decisions about things they have zero credentials in. 

In November 2016 we quit earning pension because many younger members voted it away to get a 10k bonus immediately which was gone in no time of course that is a HUGE deterioration in benefits. During the re-vote in December 2015, the Toxic CEO behind all this who created the toxic culture that led to the MCAS failure and lives lost, was out looking for a 10 million dollar house with his wife to compliment his 3 million dollar house in the same neighborhood. Of course the far more personable CEO who replaced him got all the blame and was left holding the bag as it were. Shameful.

review_title: People can get lost so its important to take control of your direction
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Benefits are deceit for union, but less so for non-union. Tuition payment is a big plus for those who want to pursue another degree or certificate. Big enough to move around and find other opportunities if you really look and network.
cons: Really big company and subpar performers can coast way to long requiring so much extra work. Cost cutting is a monthly exercise and having to defend your project 4-6 times a year after each approval is disheartening for those who want to actually just be productive and work to an end goal without it constantly shifting for reasons more then yearly strategy alignment or financial woes. Alignment between IT and Eng is non existent until the CEO level and many times the priorities between the two are competing causing stalled progress in the form of years.
